quiz.title: Unit 3: Elasticity and Consumer Choice (Quiz 10 — Consumer Behavior)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Consumer Choice & Behavioral Insights
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Utility Maximization, Income/Substitution Effects, Indifference Curves, Giffen/Veblen Goods, Behavioral Economics, Marginal Utility, Consumer Surplus

questions.question: A consumer maximizes utility when:
options: Total utility is maximized regardless of prices
Marginal utility per dollar spent is equal for all goods
The marginal utility of each good is zero
The budget constraint is maximally stretched
questions.explanation: Utility is maximized when **MUx/Px = MUy/Py** — the marginal utility per dollar spent is equal across all goods, given the budget constraint.

questions.question: The substitution effect of a price increase for a normal good leads the consumer to:
questions.explanation: Substitution effect (holding utility constant): when price rises, the good becomes relatively more expensive → consumer substitutes away from it → **buys less**.

questions.question: A Giffen good is characterized by:
questions.explanation: A **Giffen good** is an inferior good for which the income effect outweighs the substitution effect, resulting in an **upward‑sloping demand curve** (quantity demanded rises when price rises).

questions.question: If the price of a good falls, the income effect for an inferior good will:
questions.explanation: For an inferior good, a price fall increases real income, which **reduces** quantity demanded (income effect works opposite to substitution effect).

questions.question: Indifference curves cannot intersect because:
options: It would violate the assumption of transitivity
Consumers always prefer more to less
questions.explanation: Intersecting indifference curves would imply inconsistent preferences (same bundle yielding different utility levels), violating the **axiom of transitivity** in consumer theory.

questions.question: A Veblen good violates the law of demand because:
options: It is an inferior good with a strong income effect
Its demand increases as price rises due to perceived status
It is a necessity with no substitutes
questions.explanation: **Veblen goods** (luxury status goods) have upward‑sloping demand because higher price increases prestige/desirability, overriding the normal substitution effect.

questions.question: Diminishing marginal utility implies that:
options: Each additional unit consumed adds less to total utility
Consumers should only buy one unit of a good
Marginal utility becomes negative after the first unit
questions.explanation: **Diminishing marginal utility**: as more of a good is consumed, the additional satisfaction from each extra unit declines.

questions.question: If a consumer is at a bundle where MRS > Px/Py, they can increase utility by:
options: Buying more X and less Y
Buying more Y and less X
questions.explanation: MRS > Px/Py means the consumer values X more relative to Y than the market price ratio suggests → should **consume more X, less Y** until MRS = Px/Py.

questions.question: Behavioral economics suggests consumers sometimes violate the assumption of rationality by:
options: Always maximizing marginal utility per dollar
Exhibiting bounded rationality and present bias
questions.explanation: Behavioral economics introduces **bounded rationality, present bias, loss aversion, and framing effects** — systematic departures from perfect rationality assumed in traditional models.

questions.question: When the price of a normal good rises, the total effect on quantity demanded is:
options: A decrease due to both substitution and income effects
An increase due to the income effect
An increase due to the substitution effect
questions.explanation: For a normal good, price rise → substitution effect (buy less) and income effect (real income falls, buy less) **both reduce quantity demanded**.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent grasp of advanced consumer theory: utility maximization, income/substitution effects, Giffen/Veblen goods, indifference curve properties, and behavioral insights.
scoreMessages.70: Strong understanding; review Giffen vs. Veblen goods, the role of MRS, and how behavioral economics challenges traditional rationality.
scoreMessages.50: Good on basics; work on: 1) Income vs. substitution effects for normal/inferior goods, 2) Indifference curve assumptions, 3) Marginal utility vs. total utility, 4) MRS and price ratio rule.
scoreMessages.0: Revisit Unit 3 consumer choice fundamentals: utility, budget constraints, income/substitution effects, and the law of diminishing marginal utility.
